case_vignette: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10.1-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His achilles reflex is 1+.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a cough for the past 3 months and it's gotten harder for me to walk up the stairs.
How old are you?
I'm 53 years old.
Do you have a history of smoking?
Yes, I've smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years.
Do you have a family history of lung disease or cancer?
The vignette doesn't mention any family history of lung disease or cancer.

Yes, I've lost 10.1 pounds over the past 6 months.

The vignette doesn't mention any medications that I'm taking.
**Final Diagnosis:** Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
